caption:
This photograph displays a massive, ancient tree with a prominently gnarled and twisted trunk, suggesting a yew tree or a similar old woodland species. The bark of the tree is rugged and deeply furrowed, featuring various dark shadows that give the impression of depth and complexity to the treeâ€™s structure. Such trees are often found in temperate climate zones and can be incredibly old, with some yew trees believed to live for thousands of years.

The tree is surrounded by dense, lush greenery which includes smaller plants and possibly ferns and ivy, enveloping the base and partially climbing up the trunk, emphasizing the tree's integration with its natural environment. The background is softly illuminated, possibly by a cloudy or misty sky, enhancing the mystical and ancient atmosphere of the scene. The lighting is subdued, casting gentle highlights and shadows across the tree and the surrounding vegetation, contributing to a serene and somewhat ethereal woodland setting. This type of environment is typical of old forests where such ancient trees are protected and revered.
title: Knarled root base of the oldest western red cedar alive in the Olympic National Park. Near Seattle, Washington. From the Environmental Protection Agency's Project DOCUMERICA collection, "In Praise of Forests". For additional images see fiche #s 209, 210, 211, 212, and 213. ENTHEOS. Spring, 1975.
